Name: ORZID LIVER SECRETORY OR METABLIC IMPAIRMENT

Contents.Text: Follow facility specific guidelines for prescribing and dispensing oseltamivir
Acute bacterial prostatitis is an acute infection in young and middle aged
men that is usually caused by the same organisms that cause urinary tract
infection. I is mostly caused by gram negative bacteria such as E. coli,
coliforms, and enterococcus species but sexually transmitted pathogens
such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis can also be the
cause in sexually active men. Typical symptoms include fever, chills,
malaise, myalgia, dysuria, pelvic/perineal pain, and cloudy urine. The
prostate is generally warm, red, firm, and very tender. Complications that
can occur, especially with a delay in antibiotics, include bacteremia,
epididymitis, prostatic abscess, extension or metastasis to other
locations, and conversion to chronic prostatitis.

*Most cases of acute sinusitis are viral. Most of these resolve within 7 days.
Nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and tooth or facial pain can be
treated with decongstants, analgesics, and nasal saline. Bacterial infection
is more likely the causative agent when symptoms are present for >/= 10 days,
fever >/= 102, and purulent discharge or facial pain for 3-4 consecutive days
or worsening symptoms following a typical viral infection. Antimicrobials
are indicated in these instances. Nasal saline and intranasal corticosteroids
*If symptoms fail to respond or recur after 3-5 days of antimicrobial, puncture
and aspiration of sinuses is necessary to identify pathogens. ENT

Name: ORZID2 ARTHRITIS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE

Contents.Text: Most cases respond to a 28day course of oral antimicrobials. If symptoms
persist or recur, consult ID or Rheumatology
*Aspiration of oropharyngeal or gastric contents induces inflammation and
is often accompanied by fever and/or an infiltrate. Bacterial pneumonia
occurs in a minority of patients who aspirate, typically about 3 days
later. The patient usually improves for the first 2 days and then worsens
as bacterial pneumonia develops with increased fever, new or progressive
infiltrates, leukocytosis, and newly purulent sputum.
*Therapy directed towards anaerobic pathogens is usually unnecessary.
If pneumonia is confirmed, treat as:

circumstances. If pneumonia is suspected, order a chest x-ray. If an
infiltrate is not present, the patient does not have pneumonia and does not

*Acute Bronchitis in an otherwise HEALTHY PATIENT
-Antimicrobials provide no benefit. If bronchitis persisted beyond 2 weeks,
additional diagnostic workupis needed to find a cause. If a patient has

*Acute bronchitis in a patient with COPD
corticosteroids. Antimicrobials provide small benefit for about 50% of

courses of antimicrobials are associated with colonization by resistant

Contents.Text: Cellulitis refers to inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissue
and is often associated with bacterial pathogens. The most common
pathogens are group A streptocooci and staphylococcus aureus. Group
B streptococci are associated with cellulitis in elderly people, in those
with diabetes mellitus, and on feet and legs of people with athlete's
Mild to moderate cases can be treated with oral antimicrobials. Severe
cases should be treated initially with intravenous antimicrobials. Switch
to oral drugs after clinical improvement
Mild to Moderate Cellulitis- Treat 10-14 days

Chronic bacterial prostatitis involves chronic inflammation of the prostate
with positive urine or prostatic fluid cultures. Patients may present with
recurrent urinary tract infections with repeated isolation of the same
pathogen in the urine. Some patients may be asymptomatic but have
recurrent bacteremia. Common symptoms may include urinary frequency,
dysuria, urgency, perineal discomfort, and low grade fever. Common
pathogens associated with infection are Enterobacteriaceae, Enterococci,
P. aeruginosa, and less commonly Burkholderia pseudomallei

Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but inflammation often
extends into the urethra. Typical symptoms and signs include dysuria, increased
urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
*Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in pre-menopausal, non-pregnant,
sexually active young women. In men with mild to moderate symptoms without
complicating conditions and without recent treatment relapse or recurrence,
cystitis is considered uncomplicated. Most cases of complicated cystitis are
associasted with Escherichia coli, but more resistant pathogens occur, including
the Gram positive pathogens staphylococci and enterococci. Urine culture should
be obtained before antimicrobials are given.
*Complicating conditions- consider complicated if one or more of the following
*Metabolic abnormalities that reduce local host defenses (ie diabetes,
*Treatment failure or relapse or recurrence of infection
*Structural abnormalities (ie presence of obstruction, catheter or nephrostomy
Mild: local infection involving only the skin and subcutaneous
tissue (no involvement of deeper tissue and no systemic toxicity).
If erythema must be >0.5cm to </=2cm around the site
Moderate: may involve deeper tissue but no systemic toxicity. If
Severe: deep infection or local infection with systemic toxicity
Pseudomonas: suspect and treat for pseudomonas if either of the following:
recently traveled to warm climate location or frequent exposure of the

Name: ORZID2 ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
DisplayText: Erythema Migrans Associated with Lyme Disease

Contents.Text: Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in half of
cases. It is typically an erythematous circular rash with induation and
central clearing (although other patterns occur) and it usually
develops at the site of the bite and/or in one or more distant
locations. The rash occurs 3-30 days after the bite. Rashes with onset
less than 3 days after a tick biter are not from Lyme Disease
A recent study showed that a 10 day course of antimicrobialsis as
effective as a 21 day course in treating erythema migrans

Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder but inflammation often
extends into the urethra.  Typical symptoms and signs include dysuria, increased
urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Pyelonephritis refers to infection of the kidney, renal pelvis or ureter.
Typical symptoms and signs include flank pain or tenderness, chills and/or
fever.  The urinalysis may have white cell casts. Signs or symptoms of cystitis
> Structural abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter or
> Metabolic abnormalities that reduce local host defenses (e.g. diabetes,
Prevention of urinary tract infections in patients who are incontinent of urine,
In most infants, children, and young adults, urine typically has few or no
these groups, it often results from a recognizable risk factor like congenital
or acquired structural abnormalities in children or young adults or sexual
intercourse in young women.  As men and women progress through middle age and
beyond, bacteriuria is increasingly prevalent because of laxity of the urinary
sphincter and urethra or supporting pelvic structures and prostatic hypertrophy.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria is present in the majority of elderly people with
chronic illness.  Asymptomatic bacteriuria is not harmful and should not be
treated with antimicrobials except in pregnant women or just before and during
When patients present with urinary tract infection (UTI) symptoms, obtain
urinalysis with microscopic examination.  Depending on symptoms and signs,
clinicians should also order semi-quantitative urine culture, blood cultures,
Treatment and follow-up plans depend on whether an infection is considered
"complicated" or "uncomplicated."  Infection is considered complicated when one
or more of the following is present:
> Treatment failure or relapse or recurrence of infection
Use indwelling (Foley) catheters only when needed for careful fluid management
or in cases where diapers or intermittent straight-catheterization are not
possible.  Indwelling catheters substantially increase the risk of symptomatic
urinary tract infection and subsequent septicemia and death.  Treatment of
recurrent infections in people with indwelling catheters selects for resistant
organisms, which are difficult to treat.  These resistant organisms represent a
threat to the catheterized patients and others in the environment.
Individuals who cannot drain their bladders are best managed with intermittent
straight catheterization.  The bladder should be drained 5 or 6 times daily to
simulate normal bladder function and effectively prevent cystitis.  Individuals
who are incontinent from structural, physiological, or mental dysfunction should
wear diapers. This keeps the bladder and urethra free of foreign bodies, allows
them to drain, and reduces the incidence of urinary tract infection to
background levels.  Modern, disposable diapers are convenient, non-obtrusive,
Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
The nature and circumstances of a possible previous reaction including the
timing should be considered.  In many cases, previous reactions are clearly
Type I or immediate reactions present with urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm,
or anaphylaxis and occur within minutes or hours of exposure.
Type III or late reactions present with a rash, usually macular and/or papular
and occur 3 to 14 days after exposure.
Repeated exposures lead to reactions that are of the same type.
Patients allergic to penicillins will have a cross-reaction to cephalosporins 3%
to 5% of the time.  Patients allergic to cephalosporins will have a cross-
reaction to penicillins 3% to 5% of the time.  Neither penicillin- or
cephalosporin-allergic patients will react to aztreonam.
If a patient has had a Type III reaction in the past, it is relatively safe to
treat with the same class again.  Often the rash will not recur.  If it does, it
will rarely be life threatening and will often disappear even if the drug is
A patient with previous Type I reaction to a beta-lactam can be desensitized and
then receive therapeutic doses of the same class within a day.  Severe
reactions during desensitization are uncommon.  Pharmacy service must be
contacted for assistance and drug preparation.  Infectious Disease consultation

Do not use antimotility or antimicrobial agents as they often increase exposure

Contents.Text: ELEMENTS OF A CDSS ADVICE PAGE
Advice pages are comprised of the following elements:
TYPICALLY present on an advice page
1.  Diagnosis or condition label-centered at the top of each advice page.
2.  Treatment.  Empirical treatment as well as treatment for selected pathogens
is presented with links to antimicrobial quick orders unless stated otherwise.
In addition to the drug, dose, and route, each quick order text includes the
drug's approximate cost per day and coding for important drug properties of
note. Drugs clustered together are considered equivalent.
3.  Help.  At the top of the each advice page.  There are links to a variety
of resources (susceptibilities, important drug properties, section-specific
4.  References.  At the bottom on each advice page.  These are link key
references for the recommendation s on the page.
5.  Review date.  The expert panel review date is noted at the bottom of
1.  (Treatment) Alternative.  Following the (preferred) Treatment section with
quick orders for common alternative antimicrobials. Antimicrobial listed under
each alternative header are equivalents among those listed.  A broader selection
of medications can be accessed through the "Need an alternative" page within the
help section.  For some conditions we recommend alternative antimicrobials when
recommended drugs are not suitable for an individual patient.  Unless otherwise
stated drugs clustered together under "Alternatives" are considered equivalent.
If none of the recommended or alternative drugs is suitable you can find more
drugs by clicking on the "Need an alternative" link at the top of the page.
2.  Consults.  At the top of the page, these are consultation requests pertinent
to the clinical problem addressed by the page.  Links to context-specific
consults can be found on advice pages, as appropriate.  For example, the herpes
simplex encephalitis page contains a link to q request for neurology consult.
3.  Resources.  Pertinent to the clinical problem and addressed by the page
is provided for example.  For some pages, supplemental resources have been
identified (e.g., PORT score calculator for Community Aquired Pneumonia,
diagnostic tools, Epidemiology, etc.) the information is included on the advice

Contents.Text: CDC. Sexually Transmitted Diseases Treatment Guidelines, 2015. MMWR Morbidity
Most acute disease is self-limited, and the virus does not cause chronic
disease.  No specific antiviral therapy is available.
Patients who appear to be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with
mental status changes should receive supportive treatment.  Fulminant hepatitis
is suggested by increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased
liver size, or decreasing serum albumin.  Supportive treatment includes
maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction
of coagulation defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition
Prevention for persons with continuing high risk of disease
Vaccine should be offered to persons at high risk of hepatitis A infection: men
who have sex with men, travelers to endemic areas likely to be exposed, illegal
drug users, persons at occupational risk of disease, persons with chronic liver
Prevention for persons with a specific, defined exposure
Post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to persons with substantial exposure
to hepatitis A.  Specifically, persons exposed to acute hepatitis through
household or sexual contact, persons who attend or work in a day care center
with a recent case, or employee or patron of a restaurant with a food handler
with hepatitis. Post exposure prophylaxis must be given within 2 weeks of
exposure.  Vaccine can be given at the same time as immune-globulin.
Give Immune globulin 0.02 ml/kg IM x 1 <AND>
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months

should receive supportive treatment.  Fulminant hepatitis is suggested by

decreasing serum albumin.  Supportive treatment includes maintenance of fluid
and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction of coagulation
defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition with a low-
protein diet. Antiviral therapy is not indicated.  Gastroenterology consult
Antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B is a complicated, highly specialized

severe hepatic insufficiency (Child-Pugh score over 9), no dosing information is
available.  Consult infectious diseases for advice.

Dose adjustments for renal or hepatic insufficiency:
For patients with mild-moderate liver insufficiency (Child-Pugh score 5-9) - use
the standard loading dose, and reduce the maintenance dose by 50%.
For patients with severe liver insufficiency (Child-Pugh score greater than 9) -
use only if benefit outweights risk and monitor closely for toxicity.
Voriconazole is a strong enzyme inhibitor with many drug interactions, including
cyclosporine (cut the dose of cyclosporine into one-half while patient is taking
voriconazole), tacrolimus (cut the tacrolimus dose into one-third while the
patient is taking voriconazole), warfarin, sirolimus, HMG-CoA reductase
inhibitors ("statins"), benzodiazepines, calcium channel blockers, more.
Consult Micromedex, Up-to-date, or a pharmacist for more information.
Voriconazole levels are decreased in the presence of cytochrome p450 enzyme
inducers.  When it is administered concurrently with rifampin, phenytoin,
carbamazepine, phenobarbital or other inducers, double the voriconazole dose.

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
Any patient may be infected with potential pathogens on skin, in non-sterile
body cavities, and in tissues and bodily fluids.  Practice standard precautions
with all patients.  Wash hands or use alcohol handrub before and after contact
with patients or fomites.  Use gloves, gowns, masks, and protective eyewear when
needed to prevent exposure or transmission of body substances.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX INFECT CTRL CONTACT PRECAUT

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
Use for patients known to be colonized by or infected with vancomycin-resistant
enterococcus (VRE) or other multi-drug resistant bacteria.  In addition to
standard precautions, place the patient in a private room.  Discard disposal
items after use with this patient.  Disinfect reusable items between use with
different patients  (e.g., commode, blood pressure cuff, thermometer,
stethoscope, slide board).  Wear gloves when entering the room, and change
gloves between separate tasks on the same patient.  Wear a gown for any contact
with the patient or environmental surfaces.  Wash hands or apply alcohol handrub

Haemophilus influenzae disease, pertussis.  Place the patient in a private room
if possible.  If a private room is not available, place a barrier, such as a
droplet precautions until 24 hours of antimicrobial therapy have been given. In
addition to standard precautions, wear a surgical mask when coming within three
between patients.  For H. influenzae and meningococcal disease, continue droplet

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX INFECT CTRL NEUT PRECAUT

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
Use for patients with absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 500 cells/ml.
In addition to standard precautions, place the patient in a private,positive-
pressure room.  All visitors must wash hands or use alcohol handrub before
entering the room, after contact with the patient or fomites, and after leaving
the room.  Persons with respiratory illnesses should avoid entering the room or,
if entry is necessary, they should wear a mask.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX INFECT CTRL SPEC RESTP PRECAUT

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases

personal respirator, N95 or PAPR, is required for entry into the room.

Contents.Text: Annual vaccination is recommended for high risk persons, their caretakers, their
household contacts, and healthcare workers who care for high-risk patients.
High risk persons are those > 50 years of age, nursing home residents, those
with chronic pulmonary or cardiac conditions, chronic metabolic diseases (e.g.,
diabetes mellitus, renal failure), immunosuppression, and women in their 2nd or
The use of antiviral drugs for prevention of influenza in high risk persons is
only recommended during an outbreak.  Consult with the public health department
The infection control section (ext 3668) should be notified if a patient has
Treatment is effective only if started within 48 hours of onset of illness.
Treatment depends on type.  A rapid influenza test to confirm diagnosis
and determine type (A or B) is encouraged.
CPRS Order Pathway for Rapid Influenza Test:

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITED PHARYNGITIS

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Acute pharyngitis is common, accounting for 2 percent of all
ambulatory visits in the United States.  The major treatable pathogen, group
A streptococcus (GAS), is the cause of pharyngitis in only approximately 10
percent of adults who seek medical care.  The vast majority of patients
receive presumptive antibiotic therapy for pharyngitis which in most cases is
unnecessary and results in adverse effects including death, increases costs,
and adds to pressure on antimicrobial resistance.  Typical causes of
pharyngitis include viruses in about , beta-hemolytic streptococci other
than group A in 18%, Mycoplasma pneumoniae in 10%, Chlamydophila pneumoniae
in 8%, Group A streptococci in 5%, and no microbe identified in 1/3.
Rheumatic fever is rare in the United States, especially in adults, so
that some authorities recommend no treatment even if GAS is a potential cause
of pharyngitis.Others feel it is important to detect GAS  since antibiotic
therapy can slightly shorten the acute illness, prevent acute rheumatic fever
and possibly prevent suppurative sequelae.  Other potential causes of
pharyngitis that should be considered and diagnosed if likely include
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mononucleosis, primary HIV infection, influenza,
gonococcal pharyngitis, diphtheria, and suppurative pharyngeal infections.
The Centor criteria are used to predict whether GAS pharyngitis is present.
If three or four of these criteria are met, the positive predictive value is
40 to 60 percent.  If fewer than three criteria are present, the likelihood
GAS is causing pharyngitis is less than 20 percent.  If 3 or > Centor criteria
are met, obtain a throat culture for group A streptococcus.  Treat
empirically for GAS if the patient has severe symptoms or treat later for GAS
if the throat culture is positive.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITTED BACTERURIA

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Bacteruria, (>= 100,000 bacteria per ml of urine) is found in  1 or 2
percent of healthy young children.  Bacteruria becomes more common in females
after menarche, occurring in ~5 percent of young women.  The incidence
increases substantially after middle age such that from 10 to 16 percent of
healthy people over age 55 years living in the community have bacteruria.
The incidence is 15 to 40% of people over age 55 living in long-term care
institutions.  The incidence in people with chronic diseases is increased
compared with healthy people.  Candiduria is less common, but the
implications of candiduria are similar to those of bacteruria.
Table 2. Prevelene of asymptomatic bacteriuria in selected populations.
Elderly persons in a long-term care facility
Pyuria is common in persons with bacteruria.  Pyuria is present with
asymptomatic bacteruria in ~32% of young women, 30%-70% of pregnant women,
70% of diabetic women, 90% of elderly institutionalized patients, 90% of
hemodialysis patients, 30%-75% of bacteruric patients with short-term
catheters in place, and 50%-100% of individuals with long-term indwelling
catheters in place.  Thus, by itself, the presence of pyuria is not
sufficient to diagnose bacteruria, and the presence or absence of pyuria does
not differentiate symptomatic from asymptomatic urinary infection.
Many studies, including randomized clinical trials have shown that
treatment of asymptomatic bacteruria, with or without pyuria is of no
benefit, except in three well-defined circumstances.  Antimicrobial therapy
is always accompanied by risk of harms, including drug reactions, Clostridium
difficile colitis, anaphylaxis and death.  Except in circumstances specified
below, it is best to not order urinalysis or urine culture in asymptomatic
persons.  If bacteruria or pyuria is discovered in an asymptomatic person for
some reason, antimicrobial therapy should not be given except as specified
Pregnant women have an increased incidence of bacteruria, from 2 to
10%.  The risk of pyelonephritis in pregnant women with bacteruria is
increased 25-fold.  Antimicrobial therapy to eradicate bacteruria in pregnant
women reduces the risk of pyelonephritis.  Pregnant women should be tested
for bacteruria and treated if it is detected.
Persons with bacteruria (defined for this situation as 10,000 or more
bacteria/ml) who undergo traumatic genitourinary procedures associated with
mucosal bleeding are at increased risk for post-procedure bacteremia and
sepsis.  Persons about to have genitourinary procedures associated with
mucosal bleeding should be tested for bacteruria.  If bacteruria is detected,
antimicrobial therapy should be initiated shortly before the procedure.
Antimicrobial therapy should not be continued beyond the procedure, unless an

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to bacterial infection of the upper
female reproductive tract.  Likely bacterial pathogens include Neisseria
gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, anaerobes, enteric Gram-negative rods, and
Streptococcus agalactiae.  PID should be considered in sexually active women
with pelvic tenderness and  signs of lower genital tract inflammation.  Signs
and  symptoms may be mild or non-specific, and  providers should have a low
threshold to initiate treatment. Male sex partners of patients with PID should
be examined and  treated if they had sexual contact within the 60 days preceding
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, and degree of fever.

Contents.Text: SBP is infection of the peritoneal cavity in the absence of an apparent trauma
or other obvious cause. SBP occurs primarily in people with end-stage liver
disease and ascites.  The diagnosis is made when a peritoneal fluid sample has
more than 250 polymorphonuclear leukocyte cells per microliter, or when
Long-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients who survive their first
episode of SBP.  Short-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients with
variceal bleeding, or for patients who have low-protein refractory ascites (<1
gm albumin/dl ascitic fluid).  Some give long-term antimicrobials to patients
with low-protein refractory ascites.  Consult Gastroenterology for more

Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Stasis dermatitis is a common condition that is often confused with
bacterial cellulitis.  Stasis dermatitis does not benefit from antimicrobial
therapy.  It is important to distinguish between the two.  The provider
should be mindful of the fact that bacterial cellulitis can occur on skin
with underlying stasis dermatitis. (See link below for bacterial cellulitis)
Common risk factors for venous stasis include advancing age, family
history of venous disease, increased body mass index, smoking, a history of
trauma, prior venous thrombosis and pregnancy. Chronic venous disease and
arterial vascular disease have some common risk factors (eg, smoking,
obesity) and pathophysiological processes.  The most common symptoms reported
by patients with chronic venous disease are limb discomfort (tired, heavy
legs), pain, and limb swelling. Swelling is often worse with prolonged
standing and improves with leg elevation and walking.  The skin of the
anterior surfaces of the lower legs often has brown or blue-grey
People with venous stasis are prone to develop stasis dermatitis which
is one of the most common and earliest dermatologic signs of chronic venous
insufficiency. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory process that presents as
an eczematous rash characterized by itching, erythema, scaling, weeping,
erosions, and crusting.  Longstanding cases may develop lipodermatosclerosis,
a fibrosing panniculitis of the subcutaneous tissue. Lipodermatosclerosis
typically starts with a firm area of induration at the medial ankle. As the
process progresses, the entire leg lower leg can become involved with
extension up to the mid leg in more advanced cases.  The skin overlying the
panniculitis is typically heavily pigmented and bound down to the
subcutaneous tissues. Brawny edema above the fibrotic area and on the foot
below is seen in advanced cases. Leukocytosis and fever are common in people
Chronic venous disease is the most common cause of leg ulcers.  They
are usually found low on the medial ankle over a perforating vein, or along
the course of the great or small saphenous veins.  They occur more proximally
if precipitated by trauma. Venous ulcers are not found on the forefoot or
above the level of the knee.  Venous ulcers can be multiple or single, and
can be exquisitely tender, shallow, exudative and have a granulation base.
The ulcer borders are usually irregular but not undermined. They can extend
circumferentially around the leg if left untreated.
Arterial ulcers are typically painful, and punched out or stellate. The
surrounding skin is red and taut. Some arterial ulcers are pale - others have
a black or yellow eschar. They are often associated with trauma and commonly
occur on the foot over pressure points. There may be other signs of arterial
insufficiency on the lower limb including thin atrophic or hairless skin,
poor pedal pulses, diminished capillary refill, or hypertrophic deformed
Patients with stasis or lipodermatosclerosis are prone to bouts of
bacterial cellulitis, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or encapsulated
streptococci.  Typically, stasis dermatitis develops slowly, over a week or
more.  It is often bilateral.  The onset of bacterial cellulitis is usually
abrupt, typically developing over 1 or 2 days.  Bacterial cellulitis often
starts in one area and spreads to adjacent areas.  Bacterial cellulitis is
unilateral.  Both can present with fever and leukocytosis.
In a patient with stasis and cellulitis and the physician is uncertain
about whether bacterial cellulitis is present, the physician should consider
a trial of bed rest, leg elevation, and if there is fluid overload, diuresis.
If the cellulitis improves in 24-48 hours, antibacterial therapy and the
attendant adverse reactions can be avoided.  If it is clear that bacterial
cellulitis has occurred, antimicrobial therapy should be given.
Evaluation and management are complex.  Consult Infectious Diseases.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX UPPER RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS (URI)

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Upper respiratory infections include several common syndromes including
pharyngitis (see below) and bronchitis (see below).  Most are caused by
viruses and there is no benefit from antimicrobial therapy.  If a patient
presents with a "URI," consider specific syndromes that do respond to
antimicrobial therapy like herpes simplex stomatitis or thrush.  If no
condition that benefits  from antimicrobial therapy is present,
antimicrobials will almost certainly not help but will likely select for
antimicrobial resistance and may lead to other adverse effects.

Contents.Text: Need additional help?  Consult Infectious Diseases
Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but inflammation often
extends into the urethra. Typical symptoms and  signs include dysuria, increased
urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Most cases of UNCOMPLICATED CYSTITIS occur in pre-menopausal, non-pregnant,
sexually active young women. In men with mild to moderate symptoms without
complicating conditions and  without recent treatment relapse or recurrence,
cystitis is considered uncomplicated.  Most cases of COMPLICATED CYSTITIS are
associated with Escherichia coli, but more resistant pathogens occur, including
the Gram positive pathogens staphylococci and  enterococci.  Urine culture
should be obtained before antimicrobials are given.
Cystitis is considered complicated when one or more of the following is present:
> Structural abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter or
> Metabolic abnormalities that reduce local host defenses (e.g. diabetes,
> Treatment failure or relapse or recurrence of infection
When a patient presents with symptoms of cystitis, urinalysis should be
performed to check for the presence of white blood cells.  Increased numbers of
leukocytes (usually >25) in the presence of cystitis symptoms indicates
inflammation and  thus cystitis.  The bacterial etiology is so predictable that
urine culture is unnecessary and  empirical treatment is indicated.  The
clinical significance of pyuria in the absence of cystitis symptoms is unclear.
Antimicrobial therapy is not indicated for pyuria in the absence of symptoms.

Vaginitis usually presents with discharge, itching, irritation, odor, or pain.
Bacterial vaginosis is the most common form of vaginitis. The vaginal flora is
disrupted by one or more of the following common pathogens: Gardnerella
vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, or Gram negative anaerobes.  Vaginal pH should
be measured and  the specimen should be examined under the microscope.
The vaginal pH is greater than 4.5, the discharge is homogenous and  gray-white,
and  the specimen has a positive amine or "whiff" test characterized by a fishy
odor before or after addition of 10% KOH.

Contents.Text: The decision to treat should be based on clinical symptoms and/or presence of
a high risk condition, and should NOT be delayed until laboratory test
It is important to use antiviral drugs early to treat influenza in people
are very sick with influenza (for example hospitalized people) and people
are sick with influenza and have a greater chance of getting severe
complications. If a patient is not in a high-risk group or is not hospital
healthcare providers should use clinical judgment to guide treatment decisions.
People who have a greater chance of serious influenza complications include:
*Pregnant women and women up to 2 weeks from end of pregnancy
*People with certain chronic medical conditions (such as asthma, heart
failure, chronic lung disease) and people with a weak immune system (due to
illnesses such as diabetes and HIV) or people with neurologic and
neurodevelopment conditions (including disorders of brain and spinal cord)
*People younger than 19 years of age who are receiving long-term aspirin
*People who are morbidly obese (i.e., body-mass index greater than or
If indicated, antivirals should be started as soon as possible.  Maximal
benefit occurs when started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  However,
antivirals should not be withheld if symptoms began more than 48 hours prior
and the patient meets criteria for treatment and remains severely ill.
Oseltamivir or zanamivir are the only two antiviral drugs the Center for
Disease Control is recommending for this influenza season. Neither
amantadine nor rimantadine are recommended for treatment or
Patients with chronic respiratory disease like asthma or chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease may have bronchospasm with zanamivir, and zanamivir shou
avoided in these patients. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the bronchodilator
Duration of antiviral treatment is 5 days.  Extending the treatment may be
needed for those patients with prolonged illness or who are immnunosuppressed.
Oseltamivir 75 mg po bid for 5 days ($14/day) [R]

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX DRUG INFO PAGE
Contents.Text: Click for drug information. ([R]=renal excretion, [H]=hepatic excretion,
Whenever possible, material should be obtained for Gram stain and culture.
Specimens from deep ulcer biopsy, aspiration, or bone biopsy are superior to
wound swab or drainage.  Pathogen identification is especially important because
therapy is often given for weeks.
While foot ulcers in patients with diabetes typically have many bacterial
species on the surface, disease is usually caused by only one or two.  When
Staphylococcus aureus is present in a surface culture, it is usually a pathogen
in the deeper tissues.  Therapy can usually be directed against the predominant
or virulent organisms found on surface cultures and need not be active against
every isolate.  To reduce uncertainty it is better to obtain deeper cultures.
Bacteria that are most likely to be responsible for invasive infection include
S. aureus, streptococci, enteric gram-negative bacilli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa,
and anaerobes typical of the human enteric flora.  When there is no evidence
that would direct therapy to any single organism, empirical therapy should be
APPROACH TO FOOT ULCER WITH INFECTION

Alternative for patients with penicillin allergy
Bite wounds are prone to infection because of the pathogenic oral flora carried
into tissue by teeth. For trival,superficial wounds antibiotic therapy may
not be necessary and the area should be cleansed and the patient observed for
signs and symptoms of infection. Otherwise patient should be treated
The recommended duration for preemptive antibiotics is 3-5 days
For wounds that later develop evidence of infection recommended duration of
treatment is 5-10 days unless the infection involves a joint in which case a
longer duration may be required (see joint infection recommendations).

Contents.Text: Patients with reduced CMI include those with HIV/AIDS, hematologic malignancies,
cytotoxic chemotherapy, and congenital abnormalities.  Patients with cell-
mediated immune defects are more susceptible to infections from ubiquitous
microorganisms that do not usually cause infection in healthy patients.  The
specific organisms that are more likely to be associated with disease vary
depending on the specific type of immune defect present, but include:
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly Pneumocystis carinii), Mycobacterium avium,
Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Salmonella spp., Candida spp., Aspergillus spp.,
Toxoplasma gondii, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus,
These infectious diseases usually have a subacute or chronic presentation.  The
best approach in most circumstances is for the clinician to conduct a methodical
diagnostic workup to identify the specific pathogen and guide therapy.
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with CMI defects who
present only with fever.  Contact Infectious Disease for more information.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis:
In most cases, if a person is suspected of having been exposed to influenza
early treatment should signs or symptoms develop is preferred rather than
The provider should explain the early signs and symptoms of influenza to the
patient and advise the patient to immediately contact a health care provider
for evaluation and possible early treatment if these symptoms or signs
develop. Influenza-like symptoms or signs include fever, cough, sore throat
runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, fatigue, vomiting, and
diarrhea. Influenza can present without fever.
Health care providers should use clinical judgment regarding situations where
early recognition of illness and treatment might be an appropriate
Early treatment alternative or chemoprophylaxis may be considered for:
*Persons who are part of a high-risk group and are household or close
contacts of someone with influenza-like illness
*Health care personnel who have occupational exposures
*Resident of a long term care facility that had close contact with another
resident or staff with influenza-like illness.
*Atypical situations (such as case clusters).  Contact state
Duration of antiviral treatment is 10 days.  Among long-term care residentS
the antiviral use should be re-evaluated after 10 days. If no further
exposures have occurred, antivirals should be discontinued.
Zanamivir is not recommended for patients with chronic respiratory disease
as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. These patients may have
bronchospasm with zanamivir. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
an inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the
Zanamivir 2 inhalations (2 x 5 mg)daily for 10 days($4/day) [O]

Name: ORZID2 GMENU FEVER OF UNK ORIGIN

Contents.Text: Cases with fever of unknown origin are often classified in four categories:(1)
classical, (2) neutropenic, (3) nosocomial, and (4) fever in persons with
HIV/AIDS.  Empirical antimicrobial therapy rarely indicated in these patients.
Note that for fever of unknown origin in neutropenic patients refers to
persistent fever that has remained undiagnosed after extensive diagnostic work
and empirical antimicrobial therapy.  New fever in patients with profound
neutropenia is a different syndrome and does require empirical antmicrobials
therapy.  Infectious Diseases should be involved in any case where empirical
treatment for fever of unknown origin is being considered.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU FOOT ULCER W/O INFECT SURR TISSUES
DisplayText: Foot ulcers WITHOUT infection of surrounding tissues

Contents.Text: FOOT ULCERS WITHOUT INFECTION OF SURROUNDING TISSUES
Antibiotic therapy, topical or systemic, is not recommended for clinically
unifected Diabetic Foot Ulcers (DFU). There is no evidence of benefit for
using antimicrobial therapy in DFU, but there is an increase of adverse effects.
financial costs, and risk of antibiotic resistance. Most DFUs need to be
carefully cleaned and debrided to remove tissue that impedes wound healing
and harbors infection. Dressing should optimally be changed once daily and
Lipsky BA, et al. Diabetes Metab Res Rev. 2015 Jan:32 Suppl 1:45-74. IWGDF
guidance on the diagnosis and management of foot infections in persons

Name: ORZID2 GMENU FOOT ULCER WITH DM
DisplayText: Foot ulcer in patient with diabetes mellitus

Contents.Text: FOOT ULCER IN PATIENT WITH DIABETES MELLITUS
may not be present in patients with neuropathy.  In patients with substantial
vascular disease, erythema and warmth may not be present and instead the tissues
will be dusky, mottled, or cool.  Capillary refill may be impaired.  Patients
with diabetes and ulcers are at risk for gangrenous infections.  If there is any
suggestion of gangrene, consult surgery immediately.

specifically to cover peptostreptococcus when drugs such as ampicillin-

Name: ORZID2 GMENU GRAM-POS INT RS COCCI PAIRS
DisplayText: Interim results:  Gram-positive cocci in pairs

Contents.Text: INTERIM RESULTS: GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS
Aerobic Gram-positive cocci in pairs are usually streptococci, staphylococci, or
enterococci.These bacteria can be isolated under either aerobic or anaerobic
conditions.  Gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters are usually
staphylococci.  Gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains are usually streptococci
or enterococci.  Gram-positive cocci in "chains" are likely streptococci.  If
the lab reports Gram-positive cocci in "short chains", enterococci are likely.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU IMMUNOCOM ALTERED MICRO FLORA

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
A rich, diverse microbial flora lives on or in skin, mucosal surfaces, and
respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts of healthy people.  This flora prevents
disease by inhibiting the growth of potential pathogens.  Disruption of the
normal flora, usually by antimicrobial therapy, reduces this barrier and
increases the risk of infectious disease.  Patients exposed to broad-spectrum
antimicrobials are at greater risk for colonization with resistant bacteria,
fungal infections, and Clostridium difficile colitis.  During hospitalization,
many patients become colonized with more resistant organisms like methicillin-
resistant Staphylococcus aureus and resistant Gram-negative bacilli.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology
Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Humans are protected by a broad array of host defenses that fall into two major
categories: innate and immune host defenses.  Innate defense operate
continuously without specific antigenic stimulation and immune defenses are
primed by and respond to antigenic stimulation.
Each type of host defense protects against a specific set of organisms.  As a
result, infectious diseases more common because of host defense defects in an
individual patient are usually predictable from that patient's host defense
defects.  For example, antibody or complement deficiencies predispose patients
to disease with encapsulated organisms but not fungi.  Defects in cell-mediated
immunity predispose patients to infections with mycobacteria or cytomegalovirus
but not Escherichia coli or influenza virus.  Suspected cases of infectious
disease must be evaluated in the context of the patient's host defects.
Management, including possible antimicrobial therapy, should be initiated on the
basis of the most likely offending pathogens.

Malignancies affect host defenses in many ways.  Hematogenous malignancies can
diminish the effectiveness of neutrophils and other cells involved in host
defense.  Tumors often disrupt mucous membranes or blood vessels and allow
contaminating organisms into hollow cavities or the bloodstream.  Chemotherapy
used to treat these malignancies often impairs mucus membranes and suppresses
Ordinarily, empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with
malignancy and fever unless they have neutropenia or a specific infectious
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology
Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Adequate nutrition is necessary for optimal host defense function.  A few days
of malnutrition can decrease host defenses, mainly cell-mediated immunity. The
degree of compromised immunity increases with the duration of malnutrition.
However, nutritional replacement has not been shown to improve outcomes in
patients with mild-moderate malnutrition.  Enteral nutritional replacement is
far superior to and safer than intravenous hyperalimentation.
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for malnourished patients with fever
but without evidence of a specific infectious disease.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology
Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Several types of neurological dysfunction predispose patients to infectious
diseases.  Comatose patients are unable to keep weight off dependent tissues,
predisposing them to decubitus ulcers and pressure necrosis.  Atelectasis is
common in obtunded patients who cannot cough or breathe deeply.  When patients
require artificial ventilation, intubation compounds the risk of respiratory
Neurological dysfunction of the bladder can interfere with normal bladder
emptying and predisposes patients to bacteriuria.  The risk of bacteruria
increases if patients are catheterized.  Antimicrobial treatment is not
indicated for asymptomatic bacteriuria.  It provides no benefit and increases
risk of colonization with resistant organisms.
Neurological dysfunction predisposes patients to aspiration of oropharyngeal or
gastric contents.  Aspiration causes fever, inflammation, and/or pulmonary
infiltrate, but does not require antimicrobial treatment. Bacterial pneumonia
occurs in a minority of patients who experience significant aspiration,
typically about 3 days later.  Typically, the patient improves for the first 2
days and then worsens as bacterial pneumonia develops with increased fever, new
or progressive infiltrates, leukocytosis, and newly purulent sputum.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology
Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
The risk of severe, rapidly progressive infections increases when the absolute
neutrophil count (ANC, segmented neutrophils plus bands) is less than 500
cells/microliter.  The risk increases dramatically when the ANC is <100
cells/microliter.  Because of these risks, patients with fever and neutropenia
to this degree should receive empirical antimicrobial therapy immediately.
Empirical therapy should also be given to patients with fever and ANC 500-1000
cells/microliter when the concentration is expected to be <500 cells/microliter
within the next 48 hours.  For this purpose, fever is defined as a single
Since infection can be rapidly progressive and severe, broad-spectrum

-Are able to seek immediate medical care if their condition worsens at home
-Are outpatient at the time of fever development
-Have no associated comorbid illness which would independently indicate
-Have an anticipated duration of neutropenia </= 100 cells/mcL for <7 days
-Do not have renal or hepatic insufficiency
-Have a MASCC Risk Index score of 21 or greater

The risk of severe infection is related to the reason for splenectomy and the

Most episodes of acute diarrhea are self limited and do not need to be evaluated
or treated.  In most mild to moderate cases, antimicrobial therapy does not
provide benefit and may prolong symptoms or shedding.  Antimicrobial therapy is
detrimental in cases involving enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.
The decision for whether to obtain stool culture and O&P or not depends on
severity, duration, and host factors like likelihood of specific infectious
agents and severity of any underlying diseases.  Send stool sample for culture
and O&P and consider prescribing antimicrobials when patients are dehydrated,
stools are visibly bloody, temperature is >38.4 C, there is no improvement after
48 hours, the case is part of a new community outbreak, there is severe

patient is substantially immunocompromised.  Replace fluid losses and correct

Contents.Text: INTERIM REPORT OF GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS
A preliminary report of gram-positive cocci in pairs suggests staphylococci,
streptococci, or enterococci.  If the patient is severely ill, is likely
colonized with resistant organisms, or if staphylococci or enterococci are
likely, treat with vancomycin until susceptibility results are known.
Cephalosporins are not active against enterococci or methicillin-resistant
staphylococcus aureus.  If streptococci are likely, treat with cefazolin.
(Note: if pneumonia is suspected source, daptomycin CANNOT be used as

Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite.  Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis (formerly
granulocytic ehrlichiosis, HGE), and babesiosis.  Patients who have been bitten
by an Ixodes spp. tick ("deer tick") but who do not display signs or symptoms of
infection should not be treated with antimicrobials unless they have been
In the U.S., these areas exist only in small foci in the mid-Atlantic states.
Preventive antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.  Contact Infectious Diseases for more
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat.  Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.

Contents.Text: ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in half of cases.
It is typically an erythematous circular rash with induration and central
clearing (although other patterns occur) and it usually develops at the site of
the bite and/or in one or more distant locations.  The rash occurs 3 to 30 days
after the bite.  Rashes with onset less than 3 days after a tick bite are not
A recent study showed that a 10 day course of antimicrobials is as effective as
a 21 day course in treating erythema migrans.

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Most isolates at the Minneapolis VAMC represent colonization in patients with
chronic lung disease.  These patients should not be treated with antimicrobials.
Occassionally, MAI causes pulmonary disease in patients who are not
immunosuppressed.  Diagnosis and management are complex.  Consult Infectious
MAI causes systemic disease commonly in patients with HIV/AIDS.  Most of these
cases do not involve the lungs.  After treatment, long-term prophylaxis is
usually given.  Consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.

Call Surgery immediately and consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.
Necrotizing infections involve tissues skin and/or deeper structures, including
fascia and muscle.  These infections destroy tissue, often rapidly, and are
often fatal if not treated promptly and appropriately.  Necrotizing infections
usually result from trauma, surgery, and/or ischemia.  These infections can be
monomicrobial (e.g., with streptococci or clostridia) or polymicrobial (usually
with a mixture of aerobes and anaerobes).  Fournier gangrene is usually
associated with mixed infection.  Myonecrosis is most commonly associated with
Necrotizing infections differ from cellulitis in several ways.  Necrotic
infections typically have one or more of the following: (1) severe, constant
pain, (2) bullae, (3) bruising or necrosis of overlying skin, (4) gas in tissues
which can be felt or seen on images, (5) edema that extends beyond areas of
erythema, (6) local anesthesia, and (7) signs of systemic toxicity, such as
fever, leukocytosis, delirium, or renal failure.
Necrotizing infections must be treated with both antimicrobial therapy and
surgical procedures (excision and/or drainage).  Call surgery to see the patient
immediately in all cases.  Obtain tissue and blood cultures and begin empirical
antimicrobials.  For several necrotic diseases and/or pathogens, a combination
of two antimicrobials is recommended including a bactericidal antimicrobial
active at the cell wall or membrane (e.g., beta-lactam or glycopeptide) and an
antimicrobial that rapidly inhibits protein synthesis and thus inhibits toxin

Contents.Text: Antimicrobials are not indicated for uncomplicated pancreatitis.
In cases of necrotizing pancreatitis without infection, antimicrobial
prophylaxis does not improve patient outcomes.  Antimicrobials increase the risk
of fungal superinfection and should not be used.
Antimicrobials are indicated for cases with pancreatic abscess, infected
pancreatic pseudocyst, or infected necrotic pancreas (phlegmon).  The diagnosis
of infection can be difficult and may require aspiration.  Consultation with
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases is encouraged.
In cases with necrosis, aspirate necrotic material (fine needle under CT or

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF FUNGAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Antifungal chemoprophylaxis is often given to patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for acute leukemia expected to have profound neutropenia (less than
100 neutrophils and bands per milliliter) for more than 10 days and for patients
receiving allogeneic stem cell transplantation.  For most other patients the
expected benefits do not outweigh the risks of adverse effects and selection of
Fluconazole is usually given until the absolute neutrophil concentration
increases to more than 500 cells/microliter in patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for leukemia.  Duration is 100 days for patients undergoing stem
cell transplantation.  Some physicians continue prevention after 100 days if
corticosteroids are part of the immunosuppressive regimen.Contact Hematology-
Patients who have had invasive fungal infection in the recent past and who are
about to become neutropenic may require chemoprophylaxis.  Contact Hematology-
Oncology or Infectious Diseases for more information.

Pertussis vaccine is given to children. A tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis
vaccine (Tdap) is indicated for adults.  A single dose of Tdap replaces one dose
of tetanus-diphtheria (Td) in the adult immunization schedule. Antimicrobial
prophylaxis is sometimes used during pertussis outbreaks.  Consult Infectious
Diseases for more information on vaccination and antimicrobial prophylaxis.

Contents.Text: PATIENTS WITH SIGNS OF INFECTION MORE THAN 48 HOURS AFTER PROCEDURE
Most post-operative infections appear at least 4 days after the operation.  If
the wound appears normal to examination surgical site infection is unlikely.
Seek other source of fever.  Consider opening wounds that show induration or
erythema.  Obtain material for gram stain and culture whenever possible.
Determine whether the patient has signs of invasive or systemic infection like
erythema (diameter greater than 5 centimeters), temperature greater than 38.5
degrees Celsius (101.3 degrees Fahrenheit) or heart rate higher than 100 beats
If there are no signs of invasive or systemic infection systemic antimicrobials
are unnecessary.  Dressing changes alone are indicated.
For wounds that require complicated care
If there are signs of invasive or systemic infection obtain blood cultures and
wound Gram stain and cultures.  Whenever possible select antimicrobial therapy
based on the Gram stain.  When the Gram stain cannot provide guidance give
Vancomycin should be included in the initial regimen due to the prevalence of
methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  However beta-lactam antibiotics
are more effective for susceptible bacteria than is vancomycin.  If methicillin-
susceptible S. aureus is identified switch to an anti-staphylococcal beta-lactam

Contents.Text: CARDIAC SURGERY AND IMPLANTATION OF PACEMAKER
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated before cardiac catheterization.
No evidence supports the use of post-operative prophylactic antimicrobials.
However, due to the potentially devastating consequences of sternal wound
infection, expert opinion supports use of a limited number of post-operative
doses.  Discontinue antimicrobials by 48 hours after the procedure, regardless
of the presence of postoperative drains or tubes.
Cefazolin is preferred for prophylaxis, as it is more active than vancomycin
against susceptible staphylococci.  Vancomycin should be used when methicillin-

Contents.Text: APPROACH TO ANTIMICROBIAL PROPHYLAXIS FOR UROLOGICAL PROCEDURES
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated for many procedures.  Prophylaxis is
indicated for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), uroscopy,
transrectal prostatic needle biopsy, lithotripsy for struvite renal stones,
nephrostomy tube placement, percutaneous surgery, or other procedures where
mucosal entry is likely or the urinary tract will be manipulated.  Consult
Perform urinalysis and urine culture before a procedure where prophylaxis may be
indicated.  If bacteriuria is present treat for the organism(s) isolated from
urine.  Refer to the urinary tract infection section, or consult Urology and/or
Infectious Disease for more information.  If urine cultures cannot be done, give
Urine should be sterile before procedures involving manipulation of the urinary
tract.  For patients without chronic foley catheters, perform urinalysis and
culture before procedure, and if bacteriuria is present, treat for 2 to 3 days.
Patients with chronic foley catheters will always have bacterial urinary
colonization and therefore should not be treated unless a prosthetic device will
Urine must be sterile before procedures involving prostheses, like implantation
of penile prosthesis or artificial sphincter.  Perform urinanalysis and culture
before these procedure.  If bacteriuria is present, treat with antimicrobials
Ciprofloxacin is preferred for prophylaxis, as it is as effective as and less

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Surgical site infections are categorized by the extent of tissues involved.
Superficial incisional infections involve only the subcutaneous space and occur
within 30 days of operation.  Deep incisional infections involve deep layers of
soft tissue, such as fascia and muscle, and occur within 30 days of operation,
or within 1 year of operation if prosthetic material was inserted.  Organ/space
infections involve anatomical areas other than the incisional wound that were
opened or manipulated during operation.  Organ/space infections should be
treated as infections of the relevant area of the anatomy.  Return to the main
page and choose the pertinent organ system for advice on management of these
Post-operative wound infections usually occur between 2 and 30 days after the
operation.  Infections within 48 hours of the surgery are uncommon, but are
serious when they do occur.  Symptoms commonly begin to appear no sooner than 5
days after the operation and may take up to 2 weeks to appear.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU SURG PROPHYL GENRL INFO

Contents.Text: (adapted from Mangram AJ, et al.  Guideline for Prevention of Surgical Site
Potential pathogens are introduced into normally sterile areas of the body
during most surgical procedures.  The purpose of antimicrobial prophylaxis is to
reduce the intraoperative microbial burden so that local host defenses can
eliminate microorganisms and prevent disease.  Prophylaxis cannot be expected to
Ideally, prophylaxis for a planned procedure in should be done with an
antimicrobial that has been shown to reduce surgical site infection rates in
clinical trials of similar procedures.  If such data are not available, the
agent should be safe, inexpensive, bactericidal, and active in vitro against the
potential pathogens most likely to result in wound infection.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU SURG TIMING DOSING PROPHYL ABX
DisplayText: Timing and dosing (including re-dosing) of prophylatic antimicrobials

Contents.Text: TIMING AND DOSING (INCLUDING RE-DOSING) OF PROPHYLACTIC ANTIMICROBIALS
For optimal prevention, antimicrobial concentrations should be above the minimal
inhibitory concentration (MIC) of potential pathogens from initial incision
There is no advantage to giving post-operative doses. Despite a lack of
demonstrated benefit, post-operative doses are sometimes given in clinical
practice.  If post-operative doses are given, they should be discontinued by 24
hours after closure of the incision.
When prophylaxis consists of a single dose as should be the case in the majority
of procedures, adjustment for renal or hepatic dysfunction is not necessary.
Infusions for most drugs should begin 60 minutes before the first incision.
Infusions of drugs like fluoroquinolones and vancomycin that require longer
infusion times should begin 120 minutes before first incision.  During
procedures that last so long that concentrations might fall below the MICs of
potential pathogens, repeated doses of antimicrobials should be given.
Cephalosporins and aminoglycosides should be re-dosed after 3 to 5 hours, while
vancomycin and metronidazole have longer half-lives and maintain adequate
concentrations for over 6 hours.  For more information contact Pharmacy or

Name: ORZID2 GMENU SURG W/I 48HRS PROCEDURE
DisplayText: Patients with signs of infection WITHIN 48 HOURS of procedure

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
PATIENTS WITH SIGNS OF INFECTION WITHIN 48 HOURS OF PROCEDURE
Fever within 48 hours of procedure is usually due to anesthesia or other non-
infectious factors but Clostridium species and Streptococcus pyogenes can cause
early infections.  Examine the wound of any patient with systemic signs of
infection, like fever, within 48 hours of surgery.  If there are signs of
infection consider opening the wound.  Obtain a STAT Gram stain and culture of
any drainage. If the Gram stain shows evidence of streptococci or clostridia
refer to the section on necrotizing infections.  If signs of wound infection are
absent seek an alternative source of the fever.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU SURG WND CLASS PROPHYL REC
DisplayText: Surgical wound classification and antimicrobial prophylaxis...

Contents.Text: SURGICAL WOUND CLASSIFICATION AND ANTIMICROBIAL PROPHYLAXIS RECOMMENDATIONS
A wound resulting from a procedure in which no inflammation or infection was
encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary
tract was not entered.  Clean wounds are closed at the end of surgery and if
drainage is necessary wounds are closed with drains in place.
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is usually not indicated.  Exceptions are procedures
in which prosthetic material will be inserted or for operations in which a
surgical site infection would be catastrophic.  These exceptions include most
cardiac operations, joint replacement, revascularization procedures in legs, and
Clean-contaminated wounds are those in which the respiratory, alimentary,
genital, or urinary tracts are entered but there is no evidence of infection and
there is no major break in technique.  These include operations on the biliary
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is indicated for most of these procedures.
Contaminated wounds include an open, fresh, accidental wound, or operations with
major breaks in sterile technique, gross spillage from the gastrointestinal
tract, or incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered.
Antimicrobials are therapeutic and not prophylactic.
Dirty-infected wounds are old traumatic wounds with devitalized tissue and those
that involve existing infection or perforated viscera.  The organisms usually
have been present in the operative field since before the operation.
Antimicrobials are therapeutic and not prophylactic.

Cell-mediated immune defects caused by anti-rejection drugs cause patients to be
especially susceptible to infections with organisms that infrequently cause
disease in healthy people.  They include: Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly
Pneumocystis carinii), mycobacteria, salmonella, candida, aspergillus,
Toxoplasma gondii, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus,
The approach to fever or other signs or symptoms suggesting the possibility of
an infectious disease depends on the specific defects present in the patient,
the nature of the presenting signs and symptoms and a bedside assessment of the
severity of illness.  Empirical antimicrobials are usually not indicated for
fever alone unless the patient has a host defense defect that predisposes to
rapid progression of illness like severe neutropenia or splenectomy.  Contact
Organ transplantation is associated with many host defense defects.  Early on,
surgical wounds may become infected.  Preparation for transplantation and anti-
rejection drugs can induce neutropenia.  Later, CMI defects predominate.
Patients become infected with exogenous pathogens and also endogenous pathogens
like cytomegalovirus that might have been present in latent or subclinical form.

Contents.Text: The main differential in a person who presents with dysuria is between cystitis
and  urethritis.  Bacterial urethritis is more likely in people with mild
dysuria, onset over a few days, or recent sexual contact.
The two most common sexually transmitted urethritis pathogens are Neisseria
gonorrhoeae and  Chlamydia trachomatis.  Nucleic acid amplification tests for
these pathogens are more sensitive than culture and  should be used for patients
at risk for sexually transmitted urethritis.
For patients who have recently been treated for urethritis
When dysuria is from a sexually transmitted disease, the patient's sexual
partner(s) during the previous 60 days should be evaluated for urethritis.
If diagnostic tests for the cause of urethritis are not feasible, therapy for
both N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis should be given to partners.

Patients and partners are often infected with both N. gonorrhoeae and C.

Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgorferi from an
Ixodes spp. Tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever
within 30 days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for
tick-borne illness. In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human
anaplasmosis (formerly granulocytic ehrlichiosis, HGE) and babesiosis.
Patients who have been bitten by and Ixodes spp. Tick (deer tick) but
who do not display signs or symptoms of infection should not be
treated with antimicrobials unless they have been exposed in an area
with an extremely high risk of Lyme disease from tick bites. In the U.S.
these areas exist only in small foci in the mid-Atlantic states.
Preventative antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain
patients who have been bitten while in endemic areas. Contact
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult

Contents.Text: Treat neurological disease associated with Lyme disease

The risk of severe, rapidly progressive infections increases when the absolute
neutrophil count (ANC, segmented neutrophils plus bands) is less than 500
cells/microliter. Because of these risks, patient with fever and
neutropenia to this degree should receive empirical antimicrobial therapy
immediately. Empirical therapy should also be given to patients with fever
and ANC 500-1000 cells/microliter when the concentration is expected to
be <500 cells/microliter within the next 48hours. For this purpose, fever
is defined as a single temperature greater than 38.3 degrees Celsius.
Initial Therapy: Since infection can be rapidly progressive and severe,
broad-spectrum antimicrobials are given urgently to patients with
neutropenic fever as defined above. Vancomycin should only be given
when there are clear indications for its use.
*Blood culture positive for gram positive bacteria prior to final
*Hypotension or septic shock without an identified pathogen
Candidates for empirical treatment with oral antimicrobials include those who:
*Are able to seek immediate medical care if their condition worsens at home
*Are outpatient at the time of fever development
*Have no associated comorbid illness which would independently indicate
*Have an anticipated duration of neutropenia </= 100cell/mcL for <7 days
*MASCC risk index score of 21 or greater

*Oropharyngeal candidiasis and esophageal candidiasis are opportunistic
infections that primarily occur in patients on inhaled corticosteroids,
patients that wear dentures, cancer patients on cytotoxic chemotherapy or
radiation to the head and neck, and patients that are HIV seropositive
especially if their CD4+ is less than 200 cells/microliter
*Oropharyngeal candidiasis, usually from candida albicans, appears in one
of two major forms: pseudomembranous form or atrophic form. The
pseudomembranous form is the most common and appears as white plaques
along the tongue, palate, mouth mucosa, or oropharynx. The atrophic form
(denture stomatitis) is most often found underneath upper dentures and
and appears as redness without plaques. Patients are often asymptomatic
but may feel cotton mouth, loss of taste, and occasionally pain during
eating and swallowing. Patients with atrophic form usually have pain
symptoms. Dysphagia and hoarseness are usually associated with lower
tract candidiasis such as esophageal candidiasis.

Contents.Text: Acute bacterial prostatitis is an acute infection in young and middle aged
men that is usually caused by the same organisms that cause urinary tract
infection.  It is mostly caused by gram negative bacteria such as E. coli,
coliforms, and enterococcus species but sexually transmitted pathogens
such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis can also be the
cause in sexually active men.  Typical symptoms include fever, chills,
malaise, myalgia, dysuria, pelvic/perineal pain, and cloudy urine.  The
prostate is generally warm, red, firm, and very tender.  Complications that
can occur, especially with a delay in antibiotics, include bacteremia,
epididymitis, prostatic abscess, extension or metastasis to other locations,

The decision to treat should be based on clinical symptoms and/or presence of

It is important to use antiviral drugs early to treat influenza in people
are very sick with influenza (for example hospitalized people) and people
are sick with influenza and have a greater chance of getting severe
complications. If a patient is not in a high-risk group or is not hospital
healthcare providers should use clinical judgment to guide treatment decisions.
People who have a greater chance of serious influenza complications include:
*Pregnant women and women up to 2 weeks from end of pregnancy
*People with certain chronic medical conditions (such as asthma, heart
failure, chronic lung disease) and people with a weak immune system (due to
illnesses such as diabetes and HIV) or people with neurologic and
neurodevelopment conditions (including disorders of brain and spinal cord)
*People younger than 19 years of age who are receiving long-term aspirin
*People who are morbidly obese (i.e., body-mass index greater than or
If indicated, antivirals should be started as soon as possible.  Maximal
benefit occurs when started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  However,
antivirals should not be withheld if symptoms began more than 48 hours prior
and the patient meets criteria for treatment and remains severely ill.
Oseltamivir or zanamivir are the only two antiviral drugs the Center for
Disease Control is recommending for this influenza season. Neither
amantadine nor rimantadine are recommended for treatment or
Patients with chronic respiratory disease like asthma or chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease may have bronchospasm with zanamivir, and zanamivir shou
avoided in these patients. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the bronchodilator
Duration of antiviral treatment is 5 days.  Extending the treatment may be
needed for those patients with prolonged illness or who are immnunosuppressed.

Contents.Text: Whenever possible, material should be obtained for Gram stain and culture.
Specimens from deep ulcer biopsy, aspiration, or bone biopsy are superior to
wound swab or drainage.  Pathogen identification is especially important because
therapy is often given for weeks.
While foot ulcers in patients with diabetes typically have many bacterial
species on the surface, disease is usually caused by only one or two.  When
Staphylococcus aureus is present in a surface culture, it is usually a pathogen
in the deeper tissues.  Therapy can usually be directed against the predominant
or virulent organisms found on surface cultures and need not be active against
every isolate.  To reduce uncertainty it is better to obtain deeper cultures.
Bacteria that are most likely to be responsible for invasive infection include
S. aureus, streptococci, enteric gram-negative bacilli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa,
and anaerobes typical of the human enteric flora.  When there is no evidence

Antimicrobials have no role for treatment of aspiration and their use entails

Contents.Text: Vaginitis usually presents with discharge, itching, irritation, odor, or pain.
Bacterial vaginosis is the most common form of vaginitis. The vaginal flora is
disrupted by one or more of the following common pathogens: Gardnerella
vaginalis, Mycobacterium hominis, or Gram negative anaerobes.  Vaginal pH should
be measured and  the specimen should be examined under the microscope.
The vaginal pH is greater than 4.5, the discharge is homogenous and  gray-white,
and  the specimen has a positive amine or "whiff" test characterized by a fishy
odor before or after addition of 10% KOH.

Consider rabies post-exposure prophylaxis for all animal bite cases.  Contact

Treat deep wounds for the first 5 days after a bite to prevent infection.  For
wounds that later develop evidence of infection but without arthritis, treat
with antimicrobials for 10 days.  For wounds that develop infection of a joint,
Wounds several days old that appear infected should be treated with
antimicrobials.  In these cases, therapy should be directed against pathogens
identified by Gram stain and culture whenever possible.

Contents.Text: Acute bronchitis should not be treated with antimicrobials except in specific
circumstances. If pneumonia is suspected, order a chest x-ray.  If an infiltrate
is not present, the patient does not have pneumonia and need not be treated for
Acute bronchitis in an otherwise HEALTHY PATIENT
Antimicrobials provide no benefit.  If bronchitis persists beyond 2 weeks,
additional diagnostic workup is needed to find a cause.  If a patient has
persistent cough with inspiratory "whoop," consider a diagnosis of pertussis.
Acute bronchitis in patients with COPD
Cornerstones of therapy include oxygen, bronchodilators, and in some cases
corticosteroids.  Antimicrobials provide small benefit for about 50% of
patients.  Typically, antimicrobials shorten duration of symptoms by about half
a day.  Antibiotics should only be used for severe cases.  Repeated courses of
antimicrobials are associated with colonization by resistant organisms and other

metronidazole should only be used when oral therapy cannot be used to deliver

Most cases respond to antimicrobials.  Relapse is usually due to failure of
normal colonic flora to re-establish itself, rather than antimicrobial treatment
failure.  If symptoms do not respond to antimicrobials, re-consider diagnosis.
Relapse occurs in 10 to 20% of people after their first episode of C. difficile
Discontinue antimicrobials that might have induced C. difficile disease if
possible.  Mild cases usually respond to discontinuation of antimicrobials
alone.  For more severe or persistent disease or if antimicrobials cannot be
Gastroenterology or Infectious Disease consultation suggested.

Contents.Text: Cellulitis refers to inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissue and is
often associated with bacterial pathogens.  The most common pathogens are group
A streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus.  Group B streptococci are associated
with cellulitis in elderly people, in those with diabetes mellitus, and on feet
and legs of patients with athlete's foot (tinea pedis).
Mild to moderate cases can be treated with oral antimicrobials.  Severe cases
In addition to antimicrobial therapy, several non-pharmacological treatments
improve the outcome of cellulitis.Elevation and immobilization of the
affected limb reduces swelling.  Heat reduces discomfort.
Prevent tinea pedis infection by keeping feet clean and dry.  In patients with
peripheral edema, good skin hygiene and support stockings reduce the incidence
In many cases of cellulitis, the affected area is usually not well-
differentiated from unaffected areas of the skin. Erysipelas is a special case
with typically a well-defined border and raised, "orange-peel" appearance.
Use broad-spectrum therapy for cellulitis arising in feet of patients with

Contents.Text: Chronic Bacterial Prostatitis involves chronic inflammation of the prostate
with positive urine or prostatic fluid cultures.  Patients may present with
recurrent urinary tract infections with repeated isolation of the same
pathogen in the urine.  Some patients maybe asymptomatic but have
recurrent bacteriuria.  Common symptoms may include urinary frequency,
dysuria, urgency, perineal discomfort, and low grade fever.  Common
pathogens associated with infection are Enterobacteriaceae, Enterococci, P.
aeruginosa, and less commonly Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Contents.Text: Need help with an eye issue?  Obtain ophthalmology consult
Conjunctivitis is associated with viral or bacterial pathogens.  Viral
conjunctivitis presents with watery discharge.  Bacterial infections are more
likely to present with thick exudate and conjunctival injection.  Allergic
conjunctivitis typically presents with stringy mucus.  If there is pus
(hypopion), corneal involvement, possible bacterial conjunctivitis, or
Viral conjunctivitis is self-limited and antivirals provide no benefit.
Symptomatic treatment with ophthalmic antihistamine/decongestants and warm or
Bacterial conjunctivitis is generally self-limited, but topical antimicrobials
reduce duration of symptoms and limit person-to-person spread of infection.  If
symptoms do not improve after 2 days of antimicrobial therapy, the patient
should be seen by an ophthalmologist.

The decision to treat should be based on clinical symptoms and/or presence of
