It is important to use antiviral drugs early to treat influenza in people
are very sick with influenza (for example hospitalized people) and people
are sick with influenza and have a greater chance of getting severe
complications. If a patient is not in a high-risk group or is not hospital
healthcare providers should use clinical judgment to guide treatment decisions.
People who have a greater chance of serious influenza complications include:
*Pregnant women and women up to 2 weeks from end of pregnancy
*People with certain chronic medical conditions (such as asthma, heart
failure, chronic lung disease) and people with a weak immune system (due to
illnesses such as diabetes and HIV) or people with neurologic and
neurodevelopment conditions (including disorders of brain and spinal cord)
*People younger than 19 years of age who are receiving long-term aspirin
*People who are morbidly obese (i.e., body-mass index greater than or
If indicated, antivirals should be started as soon as possible.  Maximal
benefit occurs when started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  However,
antivirals should not be withheld if symptoms began more than 48 hours prior
and the patient meets criteria for treatment and remains severely ill.
Oseltamivir or zanamivir are the only two antiviral drugs the Center for
Disease Control is recommending for this influenza season. Neither
amantadine nor rimantadine are recommended for treatment or
Patients with chronic respiratory disease like asthma or chronic obstructive

avoided in these patients. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the bronchodilator
Duration of antiviral treatment is 5 days.  Extending the treatment may be
needed for those patients with prolonged illness or who are immnunosuppressed.

Early treatment as alternative to chemoprophylaxis:
In most cases, if a person is suspected of having been exposed to influenza
early treatment should signs or symptoms develop is preferred rather than
The provider should explain the early signs and symptoms of influenza to the
patient and advise the patient to immediately contact a health care provider
for evaluation and possible early treatment if these symptoms or signs
develop. Influenza-like symptoms or signs include fever, cough, sore throat
runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, fatigue, vomiting, and
diarrhea. Influenza can present without fever.
Health care providers should use clinical judgment regarding situations where
early recognition of illness and treatment might be an appropriate
Early treatment alternative or chemoprophylaxis may be considered for:
*Persons who are part of a high-risk group and are household or close
contacts of someone with influenza-like illness
*Health care personnel who have occupational exposures
*Resident of a long term care facility that had close contact with another
resident or staff with influenza-like illness.
*Atypical situations (such as case clusters).  Contact state
Duration of antiviral treatment is 10 days.  Among long-term care residentS
the antiviral use should be re-evaluated after 10 days. If no further
exposures have occurred, antivirals should be discontinued.
Zanamivir is not recommended for patients with chronic respiratory disease
as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. These patients may have
bronchospasm with zanamivir. If zanamivir must be used, and patients are using
an inhaled bronchodilator, zanamivir should be taken just after the

Name: ORZID3 GMENU FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Cases with fever of unknown origin are often classified in four categories:(1)
classical, (2) neutropenic, (3) nosocomial, and (4) fever in persons with
HIV/AIDS.  Empirical antimicrobial therapy rarely indicated in these patients.
Note that for fever of unknown origin in neutropenic patients refers to
persistent fever that has remained undiagnosed after extensive diagnostic work
and empirical antimicrobial therapy.  New fever in patients with profound
neutropenia is a different syndrome and does require empirical antimicrobial
therapy.  Infectious Diseases should be involved in any case where empirical
treatment for fever of unknown origin is being considered.

Name: ORZID3 GMENU FOOT ULCER IN PT W/ DM
DisplayText: Foot ulcer in patient with diabetes mellitus (Outpatient)

Contents.Text: FOOT ULCER IN PATIENT WITH DIABETES MELLITUS
Foot ulcers in patients with diabetes mellitus are colonized with bacteria.
Antimicrobials should not be used to treat colonization.
Cases with infection of surrounding tissues signified by erythema, warmth, local
tenderness, or purulent discharge should be treated with antimicrobials. Pain
may not be present in patients with neuropathy.  In patients with substantial
vascular disease, erythema and warmth may not be present and instead the tissues
will be dusky, mottled, or cool.  Capillary refill may be impaired.  Patients
with diabetes and ulcers are at risk for gangrenous infections.  If there is any
suggestion of gangrene, consult surgery immediately.

Contents.Text: Anaerobic Gram-positive cocci, including peptostreptococci, are often involved
in mixed aerobic/anaerobic infections.  Beta-lactams (like ampicillin and
penicillin) and clindamycin are the drugs of choice against anaerobic gram-
positive cocci.  Beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitors are active against
peptostreptococci, so no additional "anaerobic" antimicrobials are needed
specifically to cover peptostreptococcus when drugs such as ampicillin-
sulbactam, ticarcillin-clavulanate, or piperacillin-tazobactam are used.

Contents.Text: Viridans streptococci are a heterogeneous group defined by their production of
green pigment on blood agar.  Clinically important members of this group include
S. mutans, S. mitis, and S. sanguis.  S. anginosus (formerly S. milleri) and
Streptococcus bovis are described separately.  Viridans streptococci are
important, common pathogens in endocarditis and can also be contaminants in
cultures of blood and other specimens.  Consult Infectious Diseases for more
Optimal therapy depends on both the disease or syndrome and the pathogen.  See
Preferred treatment is penicillin or cefazolin.  Vancomycin should be used only
in patients with beta-lactam allergy, or if beta-lactam resistance is strongly
suspected.  For serious disease, consider addition of gentamicin for synergy.
Contact Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.Text: Antibody deficiency typically leads to recurrent, severe respiratory tract
infections associated with encapsulated bacteria, especially Streptococcus
pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, and to a lesser extent, Staphylococcus
aureus. Recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia are common syndromes.
Gastrointestinal disease associated with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or
rotavirus is also common in some patients.

Malignancies affect host defenses in many ways.  Hematogenous malignancies can
diminish the effectiveness of neutrophils and other cells involved in host
defense.  Tumors often disrupt mucous membranes or blood vessels and allow
contaminating organisms into hollow cavities or the bloodstream.  Chemotherapy
used to treat these malignancies often impairs mucus membranes and suppresses
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with malignancy and

Several types of neurological dysfunction predispose patients to infectious
diseases.  Comatose patients are unable to keep weight off dependent tissues,
predisposing them to decubitus ulcers and pressure necrosis.  Atelectasis is
common in obtunded patients who cannot cough or breathe deeply.  When patients
require artificial ventilation, intubation compounds the risk of respiratory
Neurological dysfunction of the bladder can interfere with normal bladder
emptying and predisposes patients to bacteriuria.  The risk of bacteruria
increases if patients are catheterized.  Antimicrobial treatment is not
indicated for asymptomatic bacteriuria.  It provides no benefit and increases
risk of colonization with resistant organisms.
Neurological dysfunction of the gastrointestinal or pulmonary systems
predisposes patients to aspiration of oropharyngeal or gastric contents.
Aspiration causes fever, inflammation, and/or pulmonary infiltrate, but does not
require antimicrobial treatment. Bacterial pneumonia occurs in a minority of
patients who experience significant aspiration, typically about 3 days later.
The patient usually improves for the first 2 days and then worsens as bacterial
pneumonia develops with increased fever, new or progressive infiltrates,

Patients with absent or dysfunctional spleens are at risk of sepsis, most

The risk of severe infection is related to the reason for splenectomy and the
time since splenectomy.  Risk is greatest during the first year after
splenectomy and then decreases with time but never reaches the risk level of
immunocompetent patients.  Patients who have had a splenectomy as a result of
Hodgkin disease or thalassemia are at greatest risk of infection.  The risk is
intermediate in patients who have had splenectomy for spherocytosis, idiopathic

When asplenic patients present with fever or other symptoms suggesting systemic

Contents.Text: Most episodes of acute diarrhea are self limited and do not need to be evaluated
or treated.  In most mild to moderate cases, antimicrobial therapy does not
provide benefit and may prolong symptoms or shedding.  Antimicrobial therapy is
detrimental in cases involving enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.
The decision for whether to obtain stool culture and O&P or not depends on
severity, duration, and host factors like likelihood of specific infectious
agents and severity of any underlying diseases.  Send stool sample for culture
and O&P and consider prescribing antimicrobials when patients are dehydrated,
stools are visibly bloody, temperature is >38.4 C, there is no improvement after
48 hours, the case is part of a new community outbreak, there is severe
abdominal pain in a person >50 years old, the patient is >69 years old, or the
patient is substantially immunocompromised.  Replace fluid losses and correct
Cases with enterohemorrhagic E. coli typically have bloody diarrhea, abdominal

Name: ORZID3 GMENU INT RS GRAM-POS COCCI PAIRS
DisplayText: Interim report of Gram-positive cocci in pairs (Outpatient)

Contents.Text: INTERIM REPORT OF GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS
A preliminary report of gram-positive cocci in pairs suggests staphylococci,
streptococci, or enterococci.  If the patient is severely ill, is likely
colonized with resistant organisms, or if staphylococci or enterococci are
likely, treat with vancomycin until susceptibility results are known.
Cephalosporins are not active against enterococci or methicillin-resistant
staphylococcus aureus.  If streptococci are likely, treat with cefazolin.
For intravenous treatment options, please refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS.

Contents.Text: Need help with an eye issue?  Obtain Ophthamology consult
Keratitis is an emergency requiring prompt treatment to prevent vision loss.
Keratitis is associated with viral or bacterial infection, trauma, foreign
bodies, or allergies.  About half of cases of infectious keratitis are caused by
bacterial pathogens, most commonly Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., and
gram negative bacilli.  Viruses are the second leading cause.  Fungi and
parasites have also been associated with corneal infection.  Obtain corneal
scrapings for gram stain and bacterial and viral cultures and start empirical
If bacterial keratitis is likely, contact ophthalmology to obtain a corneal
scraping and give empirical antibacterial drops immediately.  Modify therapy
based on ophthalmology and/or infectious disease recommendations.  Ophthalmic
corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with keratitis.  Antiviral
Empirical treament for suspected bacterial keratitis

Contents.Text: Pulmonary and/or Infectious Diseases consultations are strongly encouraged for
all cases.  Obtain samples for gram stain and culture from fine needle
aspiration whenever possible.  Sputum culture is less helpful because it will be
contaminated with upper respiratory flora.  Classically, lung abscess is a
complication of mixed anaerobic and aerobic pulmonary infection. The initial
infection may or may not be clinically apparent.  Malaise, weight loss, fever,
chills, and malodorous sputum typically develop over a period of weeks.
Cavitation and/or abscess can occur in cases of pneumonia from a single
pathogen, commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Antimicrobial treatment should be directed against the specific pathogen.
Treat for 6 to 8 weeks and adjust treatment based on clinical response.  Oral
medications should be used in patients who can take them.

Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite.  Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis (formerly
granulocytic ehrlichiosis, HGE), and babesiosis.  Patients who have been bitten
by an Ixodes spp. tick ("deer tick") but who do not display signs or symptoms of
infection should not be treated with antimicrobials unless they have been
exposed in an area with an extremely high risk of Lyme disease from tick bites.
In the U.S., these areas exist only in small foci in the mid-Atlantic states.
Preventive antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.  Contact Infectious Diseases for more
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat.  Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.

Contents.Text: ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in half of cases.
It is typically an erythematous circular rash with induration and central
clearing (although other patterns occur) and it usually develops at the site of
the bite and/or in one or more distant locations.  The rash occurs 3 to 30 days
after the bite.  Rashes with onset less than 3 days after a tick bite are not
A recent study showed that a 10 day course of antimicrobials is as effective as
a 21 day course in treating erythema migrans.
Wormser GP Clin Infect Dis 2000, 31: S1

Contents.Text: Need help with an ENT issue?  Obtain ENT consult
This occurs most often in persons with diabetes mellitus.  Most cases are
associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but other pathogens can be involved.
Obtain culture to identify etiologic agent and susceptibilities.  Obtain a CT
scan to determine whether osteomyelitis is present.  Treat for 4 to 6 weeks. ENT
and Infectious Disease consultations are recommended.

Name: ORZID3 GMENU NEUT NOT CAND ORAL THERAPY
DisplayText: Neutropenic fever--Patient is NOT a candidate for oral therapy (Outpatient)

Contents.Text: NEUTROPENIC FEVER--PATIENT IS NOT A CANDIDATE FOR ORAL THERAPY
Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
The risk of severe, rapidly progressive infections increases when the absolute
neutrophil count (ANC, segmented neutrophils plus bands) is less than 500
cells/microliter.  The risk increases dramatically when the ANC is <100
cells/microliter.  Because of these risks, patients with fever and neutropenia
to this degree should receive empirical antimicrobial therapy immediately.
Empirical therapy should also be given to patients with fever and ANC 500-1000
cells/microliter when the concentration is expected to be <500 cells/microliter
within the next 48 hours.  For this purpose, fever is defined as a single
Since infection can be rapidly progressive and severe, broad-spectrum
antimicrobials are given urgently to patients with neutropenic fever as defined
above.  Vancomycin should only be given when there are clear indications for its

Candidates for empirical treatment with oral antimicrobials include those who:
-Are able to seek immediate medical care if their condition worsens at home
-Are outpatient at the time of fever development
-Have no associated comorbid illness which would independently indicate
-Have an anticipated duration of neutropenia </= 100 cells/mcL for <7 days
-Do not have renal or hepatic insufficiency
-Have a MASCC Risk Index score of 21 or greater

Contents.Text: In acute osteomyelitis, symptoms have been present for several days to weeks.
Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by a longer duration of symptoms,
sometimes months or years, and often dead, necrotic bone is present.  There is
considerable overlap between the syndromes of acute and chronic osteomyelitis.
Symptom duration may be unreliable in a patient with neuropathy.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture before initiating antimicrobials.
Blood and bone cultures are ideal.  Sinus tracts are often colonized with
multiple species and usually only one or two are pathogens in bone.  If
Staphylococcus aureus is present, it is likely to be a pathogen in bone.
Empirical antimicrobial therapy is the same for acute and chronic osteomyelitis,
but necrotic bone must often be removed for cure of chronic osteomyelitis.  If
complete debridement is not possible, long-term suppressive antimicrobials may
be needed.  Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
The most important pathogens are S. aureus and streptococci.  Gram negative
bacilli are common pathogens in osteomyelitis associated with diabetic foot

Treatment of ACUTE DIFFUSE and CHRONIC otitis externa
Acute diffuse otitis externa is also known as swimmer's ear.  Acute diffuse and
chronic otitis externa are both treated with irrigation.  Avoid products that
contain neomycin if the tympanic membrane is perforated.
Treat with topical agents for 7 to 10 days.

Name: ORZID3 GMENU PATH M. AVIUM INTRACELL
DisplayText: Mycobacterium avium intracellulare complex (a.k.a. MAI or MAC) - Outpatient

Contents.Text: Help page (instructions, microbiology, drug properties, etc.)
Most isolates at the Minneapolis VAMC represent colonization in patients with
chronic lung disease.  These patients should not be treated with antimicrobials.
Occasionally, MAI causes pulmonary disease in patients who are not
immunosuppressed.  Diagnosis and management are complex.  Consult Infectious
MAI causes systemic disease commonly in patients with HIV/AIDS.  Most of these
cases do not involve the lungs.  After treatment, long-term prophylaxis is
usually given.  Consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.

Contents.Text: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to bacterial infection of the upper
female reproductive tract.  Likely bacterial pathogens include Neisseria
gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, anaerobes, enteric Gram-negative rods, and
Streptococcus agalactiae.  PID should be considered in sexually active women
with pelvic tenderness and  signs of lower genital tract inflammation.  Signs
and  symptoms may be mild or non-specific, and  providers should have a low
threshold to initiate treatment. Male sex partners of patients with PID should
be examined and  treated if they had sexual contact within the 60 days preceding
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, and degree of fever.

Immunity conferred by pertussis vaccine wanes after about 10 years. The first 1
to 2 weeks of disease resembles viral upper respiratory infection.  After this,
the characteristic cough with "whoop" is present for 1 to 6 weeks, followed by a
2 to 3 week period of gradual resolution.

Contents.Text: Most cases are viral.  Antimicrobials are not indicated.  Warm saltwater gargle
rinses and throat lozenges provide temporary relief of throat pain.  Five to 10%
of cases are caused by group A Streptococcus.  Antimicrobial treatment reduces
symptoms by one day, and does not appreciably decrease risk of complications of
streptococcal pharyngitis in adults.  The major reason for treatment is to
prevent rheumatic fever, an uncommon disease in US adults.
Streptococcal pharyngitis should be suspected when patients have fever and
exudate on the pharyngeal wall or tonsils without symptoms like cough, nasal
congestion, or runny nose that suggest viral infection or common cold.  If
streptococcal pharyngitis is suspected in adults, perform a throat culture for
group A streptococci and treat only if positive.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a rare cause of pharyngitis.  N. gonorrhoeae should be
considered for patients with risk factors for sexually transmitted diseases.  N.
gonorrhoeae infections must be reported to the state health department and this
will be done by Infection Control if the culture is positive.

Preseptal cellulitis involves soft tissues in front of the orbital septum and
the eyelids.  Infection does not involve the orbital contents.  Postseptal
cellulitis (orbital cellulitis) requires immediate consultation with
otolaryngology and ophthalmology.  Urgent surgical drainage may be necessary.
Most preseptal and or postseptal cellulitis in adults is preceded by sinusitis.
The most common organisms in adults are streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae,
Intravenous antimicrobials are indicated initially for treatment of moderate to
severe disease.  Switch to oral antimicrobials when the patient's symptoms
improve and the patient can tolerate oral medications.

Endocarditis usually develops in people with structural cardiac defects.  Most
cases present without a known antecedent infection, but rare cases follow
invasive dental or surgical procedures.  Still, the risk of endocarditis after a
dental or surgical procedure is extremely small.  A decision about whether to
administer antimicrobial prophylaxis should be based on both the risk of
endocarditis conferred by the patient's cardiac defect and the risk of
bacteremia from the dental or surgical procedure.  Antimicrobials should be
given for high risk lesions and procedures, but risks outweigh benefits for low
To decide whether a patient should receive prophylaxis, take these steps:
Step 1:  Follow the link to the guidelines and determine the risk of
endocarditis for your patient's cardiac lesion (table 1)
Step 2:  In the same guidelines, determine the risk of bacteremia with organisms

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF FUNGAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Antifungal chemoprophylaxis is often given to patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for acute leukemia expected to have profound neutropenia (less than
100 neutrophils and bands per milliliter) for more than 10 days and for patients
receiving allogeneic stem cell transplantation.  For most other patients the
expected benefits do not outweigh the risks of adverse effects and selection of
Fluconazole is usually given until the absolute neutrophil concentration
increases to more than 500 cells/microliter in patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for leukemia.  Duration is 100 days for patients undergoing stem
cell transplantation.  Some physicians continue prevention after 100 days if
corticosteroids are part of the immunosuppressive regimen.Contact Hematology-
Patients who have had invasive fungal infection in the recent past and who are
about to become neutropenic may require chemoprophylaxis.  Contact Hematology-
Oncology or Infectious Diseases for more information.

Pertussis vaccine is given to children. A tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis
vaccine (Tdap) is indicated for adults.  A single dose of Tdap replaces one dose
of tetanus-diphtheria (Td) in the adult immunization schedule. Antimicrobial
prophylaxis is sometimes used during pertussis outbreaks.  Consult Infectious
Diseases for more information on vaccination and antimicrobial prophylaxis.

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF PROSTHETIC JOINT INFECTION BEFORE DENTAL PROCEDURES
Prosthetic joints have a small risk (<1 to 5% for the time the prosthesis is in
place) of infection from hematogenous seeding.  The risk of joint infection
after dental or surgical procedures is exceedingly small.  Existing data do not
support the use of prophylactic antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with
prosthetic joints undergoing procedures.  Since the overall risk of prosthesis
infection is slightly higher during the first 2 years after implantation, some
physicians give prophylactic antimicrobials for patients during the first 2
years after implantation.  In addition, antimicrobials are given for theoretical
reasons to persons with neutropenia (less than 500 neutrophils and bands per
If antimicrobials are given during dental procedures to prevent prosthetic joint
Amoxicillin 2 gm PO 1 hour before procedure ($0.56/day) [R] < OR >
Cephalexin 2 gm PO 1 hour before procedure ($0.36/day) [R]
Alternative for patients with penicillin allergy
Clindamycin 600 mg PO 30 minutes before procedure ($1.68/day) [H,O]
Patients unable to take oral medications
Ampicillin 2 gm IV ($12/day) [R] over 20 minutes, beginning 60 minutes
Cefazolin 1 gm IV ($2.73/day) [R] over 20 minutes, beginning 60 minutes
Alternative for patients with penicillin allergy
Clindamycin 600 mg IV over 30 minutes, beginning 60 minutes before incision

Contents.Text: INFECTIONS IN BONE OR JOINT PROSTHESES
Common important pathogens include coagulase-negative staphylococci,
Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci, enterococci, and gram negative bacilli.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture before starting antimicrobial
therapy.  Blood, joint fluid, and affected tissue and/or bone are ideal
specimens to culture.  Sinus tracts are often colonized and the organisms seen
or cultured from them may not be pathogens.  If Staphylococcus aureus is
present, it is likely to be a pathogen in the bone.

Contents.Text: Cure is most likely if the prosthesis is removed, but this entails at a minimum
weeks without a functional joint and several surgical procedures.  Treat with
antimicrobials for 4-6 weeks, followed by 2-4 weeks of observation without
antimicrobials.  When infection has been eradicated, new joint materials can be
Acute infections can often be cured with incision and drainage followed by
antimicrobials.  Finally, some cases can be managed with long-term suppressive
antimicrobial therapy.  Long-term suppressive antimicrobial therapy is most
effective when started soon after infection onset.  Even then, relapse occurs in
more than half of cases.  Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
Infectious Disease and Orthopedics consultations are essential.

Retinitis is a subset of uveitis.  Retinitis is rare in immunocompetent people
and is usually associated in these individuals with varicella-zoster or herpes
Retinitis is more common in immunocompromised patients.  Cytomegalovirus is the
most common pathogen (see cytomegalovirus section).  Other retinitis pathogens
include Toxoplasma gondii, Bartonella henslae, Histoplasma capsulatum, and
Treponema pallidum.  In most cases, patients have other neurological symptoms or
signs.Patients with candidemia may present with 1-3 mm white punctate retinal
lesions called "cotton-wool" spots.  These may only be visible on slit-lamp
examination.  Treat candidal retinitis with systemic antifungal therapy.
Contact ophthalmology, infectious diseases, or neurology for help.

Contents.Text: Most cases of acute sinusitis are viral.  Most of these resolve within 7 days.
Symptoms such as nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and tooth or facial
pain can be treated with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline.  Bacterial
infection is more likely the causative agent when symptoms are present
=10 days, fever =102oF and purulent discharge or facial pain for
For patients who present with severe symptoms, like intense periorbital swelling
and facial pain or changes in mental status, initiate empiric antimicrobials and
obtain CT scan of sinuses to determine the extent of infection.  If the CT shows
extension of sinusitis infection into surrounding structures (i.e., the cranium
or orbit) consult ENT immediately.  Closely monitor all patients who present
with severe signs and symptoms to ensure that signs and symptoms improve within
If symptoms fail to respond or recur after 3-5 days of antimicrobial
therapy, puncture and aspiration of sinuses is necessary to identify pathogens.
Treatment for patients that FAIL TO RESPOND to antimicrobial therapy or recur
after antimicrobial therapy has been completed consult ENT for puncture
3-4 consecutive days, or  worsening symptoms following a typical viral
infection. Antimicrobials are indicated in these instances. Nasal  saline and
intranasal corticosteroids are beneficial as adjunctive therapy.

Contents.Text: SMALL PLEOMORPHIC BACILLI IN AEROBIC BOTTLE
SMALL PLEOMORPHIC BACILLI in AEROBIC bottle are usually diphtheroids.  These are
usually contaminants. Rarely such organisms prove to be Listeria monocytogenes,
which when present in a blood culture is likely a pathogen.  Listeria is more
likely in patients with impaired cell-mediated immunity, pregnant women,
elderly, patients on immunosuppressive therapy for transplantation.

TOOTH ABSCESS AND OTHER SUPPURATIVE ODONTOGENIC INFECTIONS
For apical infections and pulpitis, antimicrobials are ineffective.  Dental
Periapical infections and deep space infections and gingivitis require drainage
and debridement as well as systemic antimicrobials for cure.  Periodontal
disease is treated with antimicrobial mouth rinse alone.
Penicillin is the drug of choice for treatment of dental infections.  Patients
with immunocompromising conditions or recent hospitalization may be more likely
to be infected with Gram-negative anaerobes that are resistant to penicillin.
In these patients, adding metronidazole to penicillin may be beneficial.
Clindamycin is the alternative for patients who are allergic to penicillin.

Contents.Text: CARDIAC SURGERY AND IMPLANTATION OF PACEMAKER
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated before cardiac catheterization.
No evidence supports the use of post-operative prophylactic antimicrobials.
However, due to the potentially devastating consequences of sternal wound
infection, expert opinion supports use of a limited number of post-operative
doses.  Discontinue antimicrobials by 48 hours after the procedure, regardless
of the presence of postoperative drains or tubes.
Cefazolin is preferred for prophylaxis, as it is more active than vancomycin
against susceptible staphylococci.  Vancomycin should be used when methicillin-
resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection is likely.  Consult Cardiothoracic
Surgery or Infectious Diseases for more information.
If vancomycin is used give 1000 mg to patients weighing less than 100 kg.  Give
1500 mg if the patient weights 100 or more kg.

Contents.Text: Oropharyngeal candidiasis and esophageal candidiasis are opportunistic
infections that primarily occur in patients on inhaled corticosteroids,
patients that wear dentures, cancer patients on cytotoxic chemotherapy
or radiation to the head or neck, and patients that are HIV seropositive
especially if their CD4+ is less than 200 cells/microliter.
Oropharyngeal candidiasis, usually from candida albicans, appears in one
of two major forms:pseudomembranous form or atrophic form.  The
pseudomembranous form is the most common and appears a white
plaques on the tongue, palate, mouth mucosa, or oropharynx.  The
atrophic form (denture stomatitis) is most often found underneath upper
dentures and appears as redness without plaques.  Patients are often
asymptomatic, but may feel cotton mouth, loss of taste, and occasionally
pain during eating and swallowing.  Patients with atrophic form usually
have pain symptoms.  Dysphagia and hoarseness is usually associated
with a lower tract candidiasis such as esophageal candidiasis.

Contents.Text: URETHRITIS ASSOCIATED WITH SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES
The main differential in a person who presents with dysuria is between cystitis
and  urethritis.  Bacterial urethritis is more likely in people with mild
dysuria, onset over a few days, or recent sexual contact.
The two most common sexually transmitted urethritis pathogens are Neisseria
gonorrhoeae and  Chlamydia trachomatis.  Nucleic acid amplification tests for
these pathogens are more sensitive than culture and  should be used for patients
at risk for sexually transmitted urethritis.
For patients who have recently been treated for urethritis
Treatment of recurrent or persistent urethritis
When dysuria is from a sexually transmitted disease, the patient's sexual
partner(s) during the previous 60 days should be evaluated for urethritis.
If diagnostic tests for the cause of urethritis are not feasible, therapy for
both N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis should be given to partners.
Initial treatment of patients and sex partners
Patients and partners are often infected with both N. gonorrhoeae and C.
trachomatis.  Treat for both pathogens unless one is ruled out by lab test.
Preferred treatment for N. gonorrhoaeae AND C. trachomatis

Contents.Text: Click for drug information. ([R]=renal excretion, [H]=hepatic excretion,
Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but inflammation often
extends into the urethra. Typical symptoms and  signs include dysuria, increased
urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Most cases of UNCOMPLICATED CYSTITIS occur in pre-menopausal, non-pregnant,
sexually active young women. In men with mild to moderate symptoms without
complicating conditions and  without recent treatment relapse or recurrence,
cystitis is considered uncomplicated.  Most cases of COMPLICATED CYSTITIS are
associated with Escherichia coli, but more resistant pathogens occur, including
the Gram positive pathogens staphylococci and  enterococci.  Urine culture
should be obtained before antimicrobials are given.
Cystitis is considered complicated when one or more of the following is present:
> Structural abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter or
> Metabolic abnormalities that reduce local host defenses (e.g. diabetes,
> Treatment failure or relapse or recurrence of infection
When a patient presents with symptoms of cystitis, urinalysis should be
performed to check for the presence of white blood cells.  Increased numbers of
leukocytes (usually >25) in the presence of cystitis symptoms indicates
inflammation and  thus cystitis.  The bacterial etiology is so predictable that
urine culture is unnecessary and  empirical treatment is indicated.  The
clinical significance of pyuria in the absence of cystitis symptoms is unclear.
Antimicrobial therapy is not indicated for pyuria in the absence of symptoms.
